text: Quantum Physics I Identical Particles and Multielectron Atoms Sources: Townsend Ch 7 French and Taylor Ch 13; Eisberg and Resnick 9 1Identical Particles Motivation and background • Wavefunctions of multiple particles must account for the fact that identical particles are indistinguishable. • Pauli Exclusion Principle: No two electrons in the same system can be in the same state. • These effects lead to profound changes in the physical world. • How does particle symmetry requirement affect properties of atoms? 2Identical Particles • It is not possible to calculate the properties of multiparticle systems in closed form, but we can understand trends and overall behavior using symmetry and approximation arguments. • Computational approaches such as Hartree- Fock and Density Functional Theory can produce useful quantitative results. 3 AND Identical Particles The Plan • Wavefunction and energies for two noninteracting particles in a system. • Two noninteracting identical particles. • The helium atom – interacting identical particles. • Approaches to solving multielectron atoms. • Systematics of multielectron atoms – the periodic table. – Ionization energies; – X-ray emission lines; – Chemistry 4Identical Particles When two non-identical particles collide you can tell which is which before and after the collision – a “movie” 5 We can write a wavefunction that describes both of the particles as a product of individual wavefunctions. Possible combinations are, ↑ (1) ↑ (2) ↑ (1) ↓ (2) ↓ (1) ↑ (2) ↓ (1) ↓ (2) The first and last are symmetric wrt exchange. Identical Particles Total Wavefunction symmetry • The total wavefunction for two identical particles is the product of one of the possible spatial wavefunction combinations and one of the possible spin wavefunctions. • It is the overall symmetry of the total wavefunction that is important for exchange symmetry and the Pauli Exclusion Principle. Pauli, Phys Rev, 58, 716 (1940). 16Identical Particles Pauli Exclusion is a consequence of the antisymmetry requirement Class activity: Show that the wavefunction amplitude for two electrons in the same antisymmetric spatial state is zero. We can therefore put only two electrons in the ground state of He. (They must have different spin) Identical Particles
